children.subject:
I was in the class for the first 4 weeks last Spring (I ultimately dropped because I was in too many classes, not because I disliked it, if that's of use) so I want to leave the student response blank for anyone who has taken it all the way through. From what I observed, the class was mainly slide-based lectures and some iPython/Matlab homework assignments and the workload was centered around these assignments. There's also a final project.

The main thing I can comment on that may be of use is what I thought of the necessity of the prerequisite material - at the time I took it, I had taken EE 16AB and EE 120 and was concurrently in EE 123. From what I saw of the class, it seems like taking it without 120 would be a very bad idea. The class (at least what I saw of it) kind of breezed through 2D Fourier Transforms and 2D filtering, and didn't explain them in much detail (maybe they were covered in more depth later in the class?), certainly nowhere near how much 120 guides you in understanding 1D filtering. I'd imagine that's partially by the nature of it being a graduate course, so there's little if any hand-holding. 16B really doesn't do Fourier/LTI stuff justice because it doesn't have the time to (yes, 16B covers DFT and LTI systems/convolution, but at a very cursory level compared to 120 which spends the entire first third of the class on LTI systems followed by an entire month of Fourier analysis), so I can't imagine attempting to understand some of that stuff in 2D without first gaining comfort with the tamer 1D versions in 120.

123's coverage of wavelets and other advanced SP stuff would probably be useful to have beforehand as well, but is not nearly as fundamental/necessary as what 120 gives you, in my opinion.

history.content: I am an undergrad who is planning on taking EE225B: Digital Image Processing. I am wondering if anyone has taken the class can provide any insight to how to how hard the class is, the time commitment, how to approach/study the material, and etc. For reference, I have taken EE16B (and not EE120) so I imagine some of the signal processing concepts may be new to me.
history.subject: Can anyone who has taken EE225B comment on the nature of the class?
